title: 113_hr3097
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Tribute to Constance Baker Motley Act of 2013". Constance Baker Motley, born in 1921 in New Haven, Connecticut, was a key figure in the civil rights movement. She graduated from New York University in 1943 and later became a staff attorney at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, where she worked alongside Thurgood Marshall to fight against segregation for 2 decades. Motley was the only female attorney on the legal team that won a landmark desegregation case. Constance Baker Motley, part of the LDF legal team that won Brown v. Board of Education, was involved in numerous civil rights cases across various courts, securing desegregation victories and protecting protestors' rights. She also represented Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and other activists, ensuring their release from Southern jails. Constance Baker Motley secured desegregation victories in education across the South and the District of Columbia, allowing Blacks to attend formerly all White public schools, colleges, and universities. Her courtroom victories were crucial in achieving the goal of ending racial segregation in public institutions and voting, a key objective of the Civil Rights Movement. Constance Baker Motley, a key figure in the Civil Rights Movement, represented Dr. King in legal battles for desegregation. She fought for the rights of Freedom Riders and secured victories for Black individuals to end segregation in transportation and public facilities. Constance Baker Motley fought for desegregation in various aspects of society, including transportation, public facilities, and voting rights. She won a significant case in the Supreme Court that overturned arrests and convictions of sit-in activists. Motley had a successful track record arguing civil rights cases in the Supreme Court, with only one loss in Swain v. Alabama, a decision later reversed in Batson v. Kentucky. In 1964, Constance Baker Motley became the first African-American woman elected to the New York State Senate. In 1965, she became the first African-American woman to serve as president of the Borough of Manhattan. Motley continued to fight for civil rights as a public official in New York, focusing on urban revitalization and improving public schools and housing. In 1966, she was appointed as a judge on the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by President Lyndon B. Johnson, making her the first African-American woman to hold the position. Constance Baker Motley was the first African-American woman appointed and confirmed for a Federal judgeship. In 1982, she became Chief Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. She assumed senior status in 1986 and served with distinction for nearly 2 decades. Constance Baker Motley passed away in 2005, survived by her son, grandchildren, brother, and sisters. The President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives are authorized to arrange for the posthumous presentation of a gold medal in honor of Constance Baker Motley for her contributions to the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems and inscriptions. Additionally, duplicate medals may be created. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medal is considered a national medal and duplicates are numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the cost of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
